Comment: The Snyder Sicilian. Played before by none other than Nigel Short. The idea behind it is to get that bishop working against the Kingside.

Considered to be a testing move of White's idea - shutting the b2 bishop out of the game to strike back with a properly timed pawn break (f5, d5, or b5) from a Botvinnik type of position. The other common line runs along, for example, (3...d6 4.Bb5 Bd7 5.f4 a6 6.Bxc6 Bxc6).

Consolidating the central pawn formation.
Consolidating the central pawn formation.
Often not necessary if played to block a pin on the knight. My intent was to play Be6 to prevent Bc4 thus damping the other other bishop and guard d5.
The pawn formation is set - the followup plan for the Botvinnik formation includes Bg2, Nge2, O-O, and then looking to make the appropriate fore-mentioned pawn break.

With White's advancement of the h-pawn, I felt that Nge2 would leave my defenses vulnerable to Ng5, h5. Thus, the plans had to be altered to better protect against a kingside rush.
But what about Nxe6 and doubling your pawns and getting the bishop? I wasn't too concerned - doubled  pawns would work to my benefit - opening the f-file and fortifying the center.

The knight can park here for quite a while to blockade the weak pawn. It's not so dim as f4 and g3 are attractive possibilities.
Another positional mistake - it supports Black's broad pawn center. Better was to finish piece development (the light squared bishop) and to get the king to safety.
Giving up the pawn to bring the heavy artillery to bear down on the exposed king (rooks in the center, queen in the center ready to jump into the king's corner).
